writing_prompt: When strange blue lights and rumors of witches haunt the local graveyard, Sherlock Holmes sets out to uncover the truth—only to find Mrs. Hudson and her broom may have already solved the mystery.
story:
"There's a report in the local paper about the strange lights which have been seen in St Andrew’s churchyard,” I remarked to Holmes one morning.  “It would appear that many of the residents are growing alarmed.  With the approach of All Hallows Eve, it seems many of the more superstitious are fearing the worst.”
“I am sure there is nothing to be afraid of,” Holmes replied.  “Indeed, it is my intention to prove that, while there may be something going on in the churchyard, there is nothing supernatural about it.”
Nothing more was said, and it wasn’t until I few days later when I was once more reading the local paper that I began to laugh and couldn’t resist reading out the article:
WITCHES SEEN IN GRAVEYARD
For several days St Andrew’s Church has been the site of unnatural blue lights which have floated just above the graves.  Then last night, our intrepid correspondent saw a coven of witches enter the graveyard, each bearing their broom, shortly after the lights once more became visible.  He believes the witches started to perform some sort of ritual and it was not long afterwards that a number of men were seen running from the graveyard.  Our correspondent did not remain, having no wish to encounter the witches for himself.
I would have questioned Holmes as to what he thought of this, but at that moment I heard a knock on the front door followed by Lestrade’s footsteps coming up the stairs.
“Do come in, inspector, and have a seat,” Holmes said.
“Thank you, Mr Holmes.  I’m not sure how much you were involved with last night’s activities, but I’m sure you are due my thanks.”
Mrs Hudson, who had followed the inspector in, carrying our coffee, muttered something which I suspected wasn’t too complimentary.
Lestrade, however, turned to our landlady and said, “While we do not encourage members of the public to engage with our local villains, on this occasion we are very grateful to you and your ladies for their assistance.  You will be delighted to hear that nearly all the gang willingly surrendered themselves to us and had no problem in naming the ringleaders.  It appears that it is one thing to use apparently supernatural means to frighten the local population, but it was quite another when it was turned against them.”
“And so it should be,” Mrs Hudson said, before departing.
By now I was no doubt looking suitably puzzled, so Holmes very kindly decided to provide an explanation.  “As I told you when you first mentioned the problem to me,” he began, “I had determined to reproduce the blue lights myself.  I had just succeeded in my task when Esme came in to clean and called out, ‘Mrs Hudson, those lights are here too.’  Before I had time to explain, our redoubtable landlady had arrived, bearing a broom together with a bucket of water.  I hurriedly explained that water would be of no use, but that baking soda might well prove effective, as indeed would the broom she was carrying.  I tried to explain the chemistry behind the process, but this did not seem to be of any interest, since she simply said, ‘Come, Esme, we have work to do.’”
“But surely, Holmes,” I protested, “you should have warned her against dealing with the problem herself.”
“My dear fellow,” he replied, “like your newspaper’s correspondent, I had no wish to encounter a coven of witches.”

metadata.title: Have Yourself A Very Werewolf Christmas

writing_prompt: When your werewolf partner insists that Father Christmas will visit them after the full moon, you decide to make their dream come true—Santa suit, presents, and all.
story:
“Have a good Christmas, you two,” Ros called out as Adam and Lucas left the Grid.  “See you in the new year!”
They called out similar greetings and then departed.  With the full moon a few days after Christmas, they’d planned to enjoy Christmas Eve and Christmas Day at home, before driving down to a cottage they’d booked on Dartmoor on Boxing Day.
When they arrived at the cottage, Lucas did the unpacking, while Adam set about his plans for Christmas for the werewolf.  He knew exactly what the werewolf wanted, which made it easy, but carrying it out was going to be somewhat harder, since he’d been unable to share his thoughts with Lucas.  No-one, not even Lucas himself, knew quite how much the werewolf retained following the transformation, but it seemed wiser to Adam to keep his ideas to himself.
The transformation happened in the early hours of December 27
th
, with the first thing Adam was aware of being a loud snuffling in his ear, which indicated it was the werewolf which was now on the bed.  He was glad he’d sorted everything out in advance.
The day was spent out on the moors.  There was no snow, and it wasn’t quite as cold as some years, but Adam enjoyed the walk with the werewolf bouncing around as if he hadn’t a care in the world, which was probably true.
In the evening they watched a Christmas film and then Adam told the werewolf that he needed to go to sleep, or Father Christmas wouldn’t come.  He’d already explained that Father Christmas knew he wouldn’t be around until after Christmas Day and therefore was making a special trip out for him.
Once he was sure the werewolf was asleep, sprawled out on the rug in the sitting room, Adam went upstairs and got dressed in the Santa outfit he’d borrowed.  Then he crept back downstairs, carrying an old pillowcase into which he put the werewolf’s presents.  He slipped into the sitting room and spotted the werewolf opening one eye.  He shook his head and the werewolf put a paw over his eyes and pretended to be asleep.
Adam laid the presents out and then slipped back out of the room.  He had a strong suspicion the werewolf had been watching him again, but he didn’t look back.  Back in the bedroom he hurriedly removed the Santa outfit and packed it back in his suitcase, before climbing into bed and switching off the light.
A few minutes later he heard the sound of steady paw steps coming up the stairs and shortly afterwards the werewolf leapt onto the bed and settled down.
The next morning the werewolf woke him by bouncing round the room, yipping excitedly.  Adam groaned, looked at the time and, somewhat reluctantly, got out of bed.  They went downstairs and then into the sitting room, to see the presents still lying where Adam had left them.
The werewolf bounced round the sitting room several times and then opened the presents which were all loosely wrapped to ease the process.  Finally, he sat down and gave one of his happy howls.
All he’d wanted for Christmas had been for Father Christmas to deliver some presents to him.

writing_prompt: At Mycroft Holmes' Winter Wonderland, the staff in animal costumes are causing more chaos than the visitors, and it's only a matter of time before someone brings out the harpoon.
story:
Two employees of Mycroft Holmes’ Winter Wonderland, both in penguin costume, were enjoying a last minute coffee before they were due to start work.
“You’d better drink up,” John Watson said.  “Wonderland will be opening soon.”
Sherlock Holmes moodily drank his coffee and glared at the penguin head which was sitting on the chair next to him.  “This really is the worst job,” he muttered.
“I’m sure your brother could come up with something else if you asked him.  Back end of the reindeer for instance."
"You know as well as I do that the reindeer is real."
"And bad-tempered, and prone to kick and all the kiddies have to be kept away from her.  She’s also pregnant so will have to go to reindeer ante-natal before she gets too big and questions are asked about why the reindeer is so fat.  Plus, I saw a reindeer costume hanging up when I was in your brother’s office yesterday.”
“What were you doing in there?”
“Oh, the usual.”
“He was checking up on me, you mean.”
“Yep.  Mycroft said you were being unusually quiet, so what were you planning?  I said I wasn’t privy to your inmost thoughts, and he said no-one in their right mind would want to be.”
Sherlock was about to reply when a voice came over the Tannoy.
Places, everyone.  The gates open in ten minutes.
Reluctantly, he picked up his penguin head.  “These kids do know that penguins aren’t six foot tall, don’t they?”
Sherlock and John waddled out of the building and went to join the other two penguins in Penguin Parlour.
Shortly afterwards a number of families starting walking towards them, clutching maps of Wonderland, and a list of the timing of various activities.
“There’s penguin dancing at eleven,” one mother said.  “We’ll come back in time for that.  Now, where are the toilets?”  She looked around vaguely and John helpfully raised a flipper and pointed it in the right direction.  “How very clever,” she said.
John heard Sherlock groan and mutter something about the IQ of their visitors being lower even than Anderson’s.  Anderson, incensed, bent down, and appeared to be hitting Sherlock with his beak, when then swung a flipper at Anderson’s head.
“Look, Mummy, the penguins are fighting,” a little boy said excitedly.
Greg Lestrade came hurrying up.  “Naughty penguins,” he said, “stop that at once.”  Then, in an undertone, he added, “Or I’ll deduct the damages to your costumes from your pay.  Really!  I’m sure having real penguins would be less hassle.”
Then Greg’s hand went to his phone, which was vibrating.  “What is it, Molly?”
“One of the polar bears has frightened a little girl by growling at her.  The father’s demanding to speak to a manager.”
“It’s a bear, can’t you just explain that it’s not quite the same as a teddy bear.  Especially when Jim’s in the costume.  I assume it was Jim.”
“Could have been either of them; I can’t tell them apart once they’re inside their costumes.  The thing is, that’s what the mother was telling the child, when the bear, it must have been Jim, suddenly pushed his face close to hers and growled menacingly, and now she’s in tears as well.”
“You know that harpoon we have on display, I think I’ve got a use for it.  It’s okay, I’m joking.  Probably.  I’ll come over and see what can be done.  But you’ll have to take charge of the penguin dancing.  And bring the harpoon.  You may need it.”

writing_prompt: Sherlock Holmes encounters a peculiar man called the Doctor, who claims to be searching for a missing cat that isn’t really a cat—what unfolds is a mystery that defies logic, time, and space.
story:
“When you have eliminated the impossible, then whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth,” Sherlock Holmes said.
“By which you mean…” the man he was addressing replied.
“That you cannot have gained entrance through any of the usual channels, and therefore you and that contraption,” Holmes waved his hand at a blue box standing in one corner, “must have come in by some other means.  And therefore, despite my logic telling me it cannot happen, I must accept that you are indeed from space.”
“Delighted you think so.  And ordinarily I’d love to stay and chat, but just now I’m on the search for a feline.”
“You refer, I presume, to the missing white Persian belonging to Lady Endicott?  I, too, am looking for her.”
“In a way, yes.  Although…” the man paused.  “By the way, I’m the Doctor.”
Holmes looked slightly disbelieving, but, given that the man apparently came from somewhere that would have suited the imagination of Mr Wells, he didn’t query the fact.  Instead he said, “There’s something strange about the cat?”
“Well, yes.  It’s, well, it’s not really a cat.”
“I see.”  The day was getting stranger and stranger.  Holmes wasn’t sure whether he was in the pages of a book by H G Wells, or of one by Lewis Carroll.  Normally, he would have little interest in literature, but recently Watson had been insistent on sharing some of his books, and it appeared something had remained in his mental lumber room.  “And how did you intend going about finding this not-cat?”
“I hadn’t really got a plan.  I normally just mooch around until something strikes me.”
Clearly this Doctor worked like Inspector Gregson.  “I have established where the cat was last seen and have therefore narrowed down the best places to look for it.  Perhaps we should work together?”
“An excellent idea.  After you.”
Holmes led the way down the passage which took them past the kitchen and from there outside into a small courtyard.
And there was the white Persian.  There was also a large tabby cat of dubious parentage.  As Holmes and the Doctor watched, the tabby swaggered off and the Persian trotted towards them, with what looked rather like a smirk on her face.
The Doctor scooped her up.  “Your family will not be pleased,” he said.
“What are you planning to do with her?” Holmes asked.
“I shall return her to her home planet.”
“I shall need to give Lady Endicott a reason why I could not find her cat.”
“I suggest you say she was stolen.  You caught sight of the man but could not prevent his escape.  If you come with me, back to my TARDIS – you probably saw what you thought was a blue box – you’ll be able to see me leave.”
Holmes did as the Doctor said and watched as the blue box disappeared before his eyes.  After which, he went to see Lady Endicott to explain that her cat had been stolen.
Then, he returned once more to where the blue box had been.  Much to his surprise, suddenly the box reappeared.  The Doctor stepped out and presented Holmes with a small white Persian kitten.
“How is this possible?” Holmes asked.
“It’s a timey whimey thing,” the Doctor said.  “There were five in the litter, but this one was the only completely white one.  The family agreed that it would be a diplomatic gesture to send her.”
For once in his life, Holmes was speechless.  Nevertheless, he took the kitten, waited until the box had disappeared again, before going to find Lady Endicott.  Although she was disappointed at the loss of her pet, she was delighted to be given a kitten and insisted on writing a large cheque in grateful thanks.
In a cab on the way back to Baker Street, Holmes decided that he was simply tell Dr Watson that it had been a minor matter, involving a visiting tom cat.  The rest of the story would be kept from the public, just as the Giant Rat of Sumatra had been.  Although now, he was starting to wonder whether this mysterious Doctor had been involved there, too.

writing_prompt: When Inspector Slack seeks Miss Marple's insight on a seemingly straightforward murder, her sharp observations and unexpected comparisons reveal that nothing is ever as simple as it seems. What hidden truths will she uncover this time?
story:
“Inspector Slack, Sergeant Lake, how delightful to see you both,” Miss Marple exclaimed.  “Do come and have a seat.”
The two men, having left their coats and hats with the little maid, entered the sitting room, and sat down in the armchairs Miss Marple had indicated.
“Now,” she continued, “I suppose you’re here to ask me about the unfortunate death at the Old Schoolhouse.”
“Yes, Miss Marple,” Inspector Slack replied.  “It all seems reasonably clear, but there are one or two small details that don’t fit in, and I was hoping you might be able to provide some local colour to explain them.”
“I shall certainly endeavour to help.  Would you like to try a little of my sloe gin, while you’re here?  I’ve recently bottled it.”
Slack smiled politely.  “Thank you.  I shall enjoy that.”
“And you, sergeant?”
“Just a drop, if you don’t mind,” Lake replied.
Miss Marple stood up and poured three small glasses, one with just under half the amount in the other two.  She handed glasses to the two men, before sitting down and taking a sip of her own glass.
Slack drank a large mouthful and then sat motionless, his eyes blinking rapidly.  Lake bit his lip to stop himself laughing, while Miss Marple merely nodded.
“That carries a punch,” Slack said.
“I presume you were expecting something rather like rose hip syrup,” Miss Marple said.  “And certainly not anything as strong as sloe gin.  I assume you haven’t tried it before.”
“No, I haven’t.  And I assume you’re going to draw some sort of comparison with our current case.”
Miss Marple’s eyes twinkled.  “Because I am a little old lady, you were sure that anything I would make would be similar to a sweet sherry.  In the same way, you’ve looked at the murder of Commander Weatherall, and decided that the gardener is a strong young man, who was known to have argued with the commander on at least two occasions, and therefore must be guilty.  This is even though the gardener took a great pride in the garden, the source of the arguments, and would be unlikely to have killed the commander so that he crashed into the lilac bush.”
“Yes, that was one of the details.  I was hoping you might say the gardener wanted to get rid of the lilac, but Weatherall objected.”
“No, it was quite the opposite.  At the same time, you disregarded the stepson, who had equal opportunity to kill the commander.”
“There seemed no reason for him to do so.  Everyone said their relationship was cordial.  Weatherell provided the young man with an allowance, which was more generous than what he will receive under the will, so he wasn’t likely to gain by Weatherell’s death.”
“I would say the relationship appeared cordial to outsiders, but I noticed on the two occasions when I was invited to tea at the Old Schoolhouse, that the stepson did not join us, despite being in the house and when we went into the garden after tea, the commander and his stepson took care to avoid each other.  As for the allowance, what has the young man been spending it on?  He lives at home and as far as I am aware has no expensive hobbies or indulgencies.  No, I suspect he has been saving his allowance for some time.  I have a feeling, from something his mother said, that the young man wanted to go abroad, but his stepfather wasn’t in favour of the plan.  So, if the commander had threatened to stop the allowance if the young man did go, then there would be ample reason for him to want to murder his stepfather.”
“No-one mentioned any of this.”
“I’m sure neither the young man, nor his mother, would be likely to admit to anything.  And I may be wrong, but it’s an avenue I believe worth pursuing.”
“Thank you, Miss Marple.  Once again, you’ve been very helpful.  Right, Lake, we have work to do.”  Slack stood up and headed for the door.
“Inspector, don’t you want to finish your drink before you go?”
Slack gave Miss Marple a rueful look.  “No, thank you.  I think I’ve made enough false assumptions for one day.”

metadata.title: Like A Squirrel but Without the Tail

writing_prompt: While out for a winter stroll, a curious ferret stumbles upon a hand-drawn treasure map and teams up with a little girl to uncover its biscuit-shaped secrets.
story:
One fine day in winter the Ferret trotted off to Regent’s Park.  He had various thoughts about what he should include in his spring production and a brisk walk would help him put them into some sort of order.
When he entered the park, he spotted a piece of paper blowing along.  He jumped on it, to discover I was a hand-drawn map, with an X in the middle of it.  Clearly it was a treasure map.
Just then a little girl came running up.  She stopped when she saw the Ferret standing on the map and he saw she looked rather upset.  He decided the map must belong to her.  Being a good-hearted ferret, even though he wanted to find the treasure himself, he didn’t want the little girl to cry.  So, carefully, he moved his back paws off the map, while keeping his front paws on it to prevent it blowing away again.
The little girl bent down to pick the map up.  “Do you want to help me?” she asked.  “My brother’s drawn the map and hidden some special biscuits for me to find.”
While the Ferret wouldn’t have minded finding gold or jewels, the idea of finding biscuits was even better, so he nodded, and the little girl set off, the Ferret bouncing along beside her.
“My name is Maddie,” the little girl said.  “I’m afraid I don’t know your name, but you look like the squirrel in my book, except you don’t have a tail like a squirrel.  And you might not like having a squirrel name, so I shall simply call you Teddy, because that’s my favourite name.  Will that be all right?”
The Ferret nodded, because he quite liked the name Teddy as well.
When they had walked along the path a little way, Maddie sat down and spread the map out on the ground.  “I got this far, but I wasn’t sure where to go from here.  I’m not very good at reading maps.”
The Ferret wasn’t the best map reader either, but the lake was clearly marked on the map, and he could see the lake.  The path they needed to follow headed towards the lake, so he set off in that direction and Maddie followed him.  They soon came to a point where two paths met and looking at the map again, the Ferret could see they needed to take the path which went lellarap, or something similar, to the lake.
He trotted on until he could see a number of park benches beside the path.  He stopped and Maddie put the map down again.  She pointed to the benches on the map and counted ‘one, two’.  Together they set off for the second bench.
There were people sitting on the bench, and Maddie called, “I’ve found you.”
Maddie sat down on the bench and the Ferret slipped underneath.
“Did you follow the map all by yourself?” her brother asked.
“I had a bit of help from my new friend, Teddy,” Maddie replied.
“What friend is this?” the lady in a uniform asked.  The Ferret assumed this was a nanny.  “I was watching you and didn’t see you speak to anyone.”
“Teddy’s like a squirrel, only without the big fluffy tail.”
“Oh yes, of course he is.”  The nanny spoke in the sort of voice the Ferret had heard when people think they know everything, when in fact they don’t.  “Now you’ve found us, would you like a biscuit?”
“Yes, please.  May I have two please?”
“All right, as they aren’t very big.  But no more, or you won’t eat your dinner.”
A few seconds later a biscuit shaped like a star came through the gap in the slats of the bench, and the Ferret happily ate it.
It wasn’t long before Nanny said it was time they were going, and she and the two children departed.  The Ferret then emerged from under the bench and trotted back home.  He’d had a lovely morning, made a new friend, and eaten a delicious shortbread biscuit.

writing_prompt: On Christmas morning, you find yourself unwrapping gifts with a werewolf who has a penchant for art, music, and classic holiday films—what thoughtful presents do you give to make his tail wag?
story:
While in London, Adam and Lucas had exchanged Christmas presents.  These including the traditional charity shop purchase of a hideous tie from Lucas to Adam, which would be worn for Christmas lunch and then discarded; Adam never reciprocated, knowing that Lucas would wear the tie simply to annoy Harry. Instead he gave him a warm sweater which with luck would last out the year before general wear and the vagaries of their job would require its replacement.  Then there were the usual books and tickets which both knew the other would enjoy.
Adam had also carefully selected a few presents for Father Christmas to deliver to the werewolf, and it was these that were being unwrapped now.
Having excitedly bounced round the room, the werewolf had carefully sniffed all the presents and gently touched a couple with his paw before beginning to open them.
He tore the paper off the first one to reveal three small boxes.  Instantly he tried to open one of the boxes, so Adam hastily removed it, holding it up and saying, “These are cookie mixes.  We need to make them up and bake them first.  See, there are cookie cutters to go with them.  If you’re careful you might even be able to cut them out yourself.”  The werewolf nodded in understanding and Adam put the packets on one side.  The cookies didn’t appeal to him, but he was sure the werewolf would have no trouble in eating all of them by himself.
The werewolf then ripped the paper off the second present and shook out the contents, before giving a harrumph of delight and presenting it to Adam.  “You want to wear it now?”  The werewolf nodded, so he tied the bandana, which showed Kandinsky’s
Composition vii
, round his neck.  “You can wear it when Harry takes you on a mission.  I’m sure he’ll be delighted.”  The grin this remark received echoed Adam’s own thoughts that Harry would hate the brightly coloured bandana but wouldn’t be able to complain as it was Art.
The next present the werewolf chose was small and when unwrapped proved to be a wooden whistle.  The werewolf picked it up in his teeth and blew it.  It made a noise similar to a bird’s cheep.  “It’s so you can draw attention to something without having to howl,” Adam explained.  “If you blow it correctly you can play two or three distinct notes.”  The werewolf experimented and found there were indeed three different notes.  He then proceeded to play
Three Blind Mice
.  After he’d played that for the third time, Adam suggested he open his next present.
This was a DVD.  The werewolf placed it on the floor, read the title and wagged his tail.  “You can watch it this afternoon if you like,” Adam said.  The tail wagged even faster.  Adam was pleased, he’d thought the werewolf would enjoy
White Christmas
.
The final present was larger.  Having pulled the paper off, the werewolf rubbed his face in it and again wagged his tail.  “You needed a new blanket, didn’t you?” Adam said.  “And this is not just any blanket.”  He opened the dark blue blanket out, to show that it too said
White Christmas
.  The werewolf bounced round in happy circles.
Then he sat down, looked at all his presents once again, and gave a very happy howl.

writing_prompt: Sherlock Holmes never imagined his latest case would involve dressing as a giant mint-green heart and wandering through a theme park called Wonderland. But when a mystery unfolds among the costumed chaos, can he solve it before the day ends—or before he loses his patience entirely?
story:
“Aargh,” Sherlock groaned.  “I thought winter was bad, but this, this is ten times worse.”  He finished struggling into his heart shaped costume, pushing his head out through the middle and then his arms out of the slots on either side.  The heart shape was mint green, which matched the leggings and thin hoodie he was wearing underneath.  “How does this look?”
John, wearing the equivalent lemon costume, looked over.  “You’ve got it on backwards,” he said.
“How can you tell?”
“It says ‘sweetie pie’ on your back instead of the front.”
Sherlock swore.  “After all the time it took to get into it.  I’ll have to battle my way out again.”
“Don’t do that.  If you pull your arms in, I can spin it round while it’s on you.”
“Hmph!”  Sherlock glared at John, but nevertheless followed his instructions.  “I see you’re ‘true love’,” he said.  “What are Anderson and Donovan?”
“Sally is ‘be kind’ and Anderson is ‘only you’.”
The Tannoy announced, “
Places everyone, we open in ten minutes
.”
“I see some things haven’t changed,” Sherlock muttered.  “Come on then.”
They were making their way to the ‘Meet the Love Hearts’ patch, trying to avoid banging into each other’s costumes, when Sherlock suddenly stopped, and John walked into him.
“What did you do that for?” John grumped.
“I thought there were only four love hearts, but I can see two there, in blue and white…”
“That’ll be Sally and Anderson.”
“But there’s two more on their way down, peach and pink.”
“Ah!  Presumably Jim and Seb have been drafted in.  That should be interesting.”
Jim stomped into the space allocated for them, glared at everyone, and said, “I don’t see why I’ve got to be a stupid heart.  I think I’d be far better suited to being a jelly baby.”
“Much as it would have given me great pleasure to bite off your head,” Sherlock replied, “I don’t think that’s quite the sentiment Mycroft wishes to convey.”
“Maybe a gobstopper would be better,” Jim retorted.  “That could prove very useful!”
“Ahem, gentlemen, I can see Molly coming,” John interrupted, feeling it would be wise to prevent the argument from escalating.
Jim, Seb, and Anderson all starting wolf-whistling as Molly, who was wearing a pink sparkling dress with a bright red feather boa around her neck, came to join them.
“Considering what you three look like,” Sally said dryly, “I really wouldn’t advise you continue.”
“Quite,” Molly agreed.  “And these heels,” she pointed to her shoes, “aren’t known as stilettos without reason.”
“You wouldn’t,” Anderson said.
“Try me!”  Molly glared at him, then continued, “Right, these are your instructions.  In a minute the visitors will be coming down to meet you.  There will be a sign up, telling them that all the love hearts have gone to explore Wonderland and if they find all six of you, they will get a prize.  Each family has a card with your mottos on and all they need to do is write which colour has which motto.  When they spot you, you are to approach the visitors in a non-threatening manner, and yes, this does mean you, Jim, so they can read your motto.”
“Can we go anywhere?” John asked.
“You may go into any of the visitor attractions – the intention is that the visitors get to cover the whole of Wonderland.  Don’t go with each other and don’t hide.  Are there any other questions?”
Greg Lestrade had joined them while Molly was outlining the plan.  “And bear in mind I shall be monitoring the visibility of all the love hearts, so don’t get any ideas about skiving off.  After all, we wouldn’t want any broken hearts, would we?”

writing_prompt: A new recruit's outdated views and inability to read the room threaten to derail the delicate balance of a high-stakes intelligence team—how far will the team go to protect their dynamic before it all falls apart?
story:
"If you ever say that again,” Adam stormed, “I will personally see that your time in this department is very limited.” As he stood up, his face flushed, and he left the Grid, slamming the door behind him.
Giles Wanstead shrugged. “I don’t see what he’s got to be so upset about,” he complained. “I simply said that if I marry someone who is also working within the service, then for the sake of our children, I would expect her to resign.”
“What you actually said,” Ros replied, “was that no-one should have a wife who works for the service, as they are risking their children’s upbringing. What you want for your own family is one thing, dictating to others is entirely different.”
“And anyway,” Jo added, “it would be perfectly possible for the husband to resign and the wife to continue to work.”
Giles looked at her and shook his head. “No, that’s not the way it is.”
Jo’s expression was such that Ros messaged her, ‘You look like an angry cat, who’s about to spit at someone. Probably better not to.’ Jo grinned at Ros.
Giles glanced round the room and then said, “You’re very quiet, Lucas. I presume your views are similar to mine, but you haven’t got the confidence to express them.”
Lucas went white and moved towards Giles. As he did so, Malcolm put his hands on his shoulders and said, “Why don’t you go and find Adam?”
As Lucas headed out of the Grid, Ros marched into Harry’s office. “Unless you want a dead body on the floor, I suggest you get rid of your latest recruit,” she said.
“Which weapon is being employed?” Harry asked.
“Lethal venom spat by Jo, strangulation with a cable by Malcolm, or I’ll use unarmed combat. But if you would prefer we deal with the corpse ourselves, I can recall Adam and Lucas to dispose of the body.”
“No, I’ll deal with it.” Harry went to his door and called out, “Giles, a word, please.”
Giles walked into Harry’s office and failed to close the door behind him. Harry noticed this, but instead of asking him to do so, began, “Congratulations, in half a morning you have managed to alienate the whole of my team. One could almost think you were an enemy agent, but even they would have the sense to know that by doing this they would make absolutely no progress.”
“I don’t understand. I simply…”
“You leapt in without any concept of the dynamics of the office. We are supposed to be preparing you to enter the field, but that means learning to blend in and particularly keeping your mouth shut until you have a good understanding of the situation. You will be reassigned.”
“I don’t think…”
“Shut up! And sit there while I make the necessary phone call.”
A few minutes later, Harry said, “Right, you’re to report to Section M.”
Giles left, clearly furious at the way he’d been treated.
“Will there be any comeback?” Ros asked.
“No,” Harry replied. “At the moment he’s a liability to any team he’s assigned to, and there’s far too great a risk he’d compromise any operation he was involved in. He’s applied to go abroad, but without being able to blend in, which he clearly can’t, he could be dead within a week. He’s not happy, but at least this way he might live long enough to see the children he seems to be setting so much store on.”

writing_prompt: After a mysterious event wipes out most of London overnight, the midwives and nuns of Nonnatus House must navigate a shattered world, using their skills and resilience to bring hope and healing to the survivors.
story:
There had been warnings about it for days, that something was happening out in space and apparently was heading straight for the Earth.  Governments had been encouraging their populations to move out of the major cities and tented towns had been set up for the many who heeded the warning and had fled.
For many within Poplar the chance to leave had never been a possibility and the midwives and nuns of Nonnatus House had on the whole elected to stay.  A few had left, Sister Julienne insisting that they accompany the women in the maternity home who were evacuated and knowing that there would be others as well who needed the skills they could provide.
Without knowing when disaster would strike, they had gone to bed the previous night, ostensibly to sleep, although most would spend the time tossing and turning as they had done for the two nights before.
And then they had woken to a beautiful sunny morning, a complete change from the last few days when the skies had been ominously overcast.  Rosalind leapt out of bed and rushed over to the window, relieved that, after all, nothing had happened.  She let out a gasp of horror.
“What is it?” Joyce asked.
“It’s gone.  Everywhere’s gone!”
Joyce ran over to join her friend.  “But that’s impossible.”
They could hear the banging of bedroom doors as the other inhabitants of Nonnatus House made the same discovery.
And then came Sister Julienne’s voice, cracking slightly as she tried hard to remain calm.  “Please, everyone, get dressed as quickly as you can.  We will meet in the kitchen in five minutes.”
They dressed quickly, unthinkingly putting on their midwife’s uniforms, and hurried downstairs.
There they found Phyllis Crane boiling a kettle over an open fire.  “The tea will take slightly longer this morning,” she said.  “We still have water, but no power.”
“And once the tea is ready,” Sister Julienne said, “I suggest we all have a good breakfast, although it will have to be bread rather than toast.  After which we will make some decisions.”
They ate in silence, each of them engrossed in their own thoughts, trying hard to process what they had seen out of the window.
They had almost finished when there was a knock on the outside door.  Sister Veronica opened it and found Matthew Aylward standing there.  “Come in,” she said.
“You can’t imagine how delighted I am to see you all,” Matthew said.
“And us you,” Sister Julienne replied.  “Do you have any news?”
“The bad news is that about 90% of London was destroyed overnight.  But the good news is that whatever it was has gone and it is no longer any threat to us.  At the moment most of the services aren’t working, but it’s hoped to provide some form of limited service in certain areas.  If we work together then there is hope.”
“What about casualties?”
“There don’t seem to have been any.  Either places were completely destroyed or left untouched.  Which doesn’t mean we won’t be needing your nursing skills.”
“In which case you can count on us.  What would you like us to do?”
Matthew looked longingly at the teapot.  “I don’t suppose you could give me a cup of tea?”
“Of course.”  Phyllis poured some for him.
“In which case, once I’ve drunk that, I can conduct you to where we’re setting up our new base.  It would be best if you can all come.”
“I fear I am not able to walk as I once could,” Sister Monica Joan said.  “But there is a wheelchair if someone were able to push it.”
“It would be my honour to do so,” Matthew said.
“Give us time to pack sufficient medical supplies into our bags and we’ll be ready,” Phyllis said.
“We can pile blankets onto our bicycles and wheel them along as well,” Rosalind said.
“And there’s the old pram we can fill with extra equipment,” Joyce added.
Matthew grinned.  “It never ceases to amaze me how you take every disaster in your stride and come up with a practical response.  With the members of Nonnatus House on our side, we cannot possibly fail.”
